title: Android founder reveals new long, thin smartphone that resembles walkie talkie
text:
Former Android creator Andy Rubin has announced a strange new smartphone called 'Project Gem' via his Twitter account.

The phone features an unusually long and thin design that appears more like four smartwatch faces stacked on top of each other.

No release date was announced for the Gem, but it is confirmed to begun early testing outside of lab environment.

Revealed via Twitter, 'Project Gem' (pictured above) has an unusual new design that's meant for users who don't want to stare at their phones for hours on end.

'Project Gem' is the second product developed by Rubin and Essential, the tech company he founded after leaving Google 2014.

Last year, Rubin told Bloomberg that he was focused on developing a phone that would be 'a virtual version of you.'

ANDY RUBIN'S CAREER Born in 1963, New Yorker Any Rubin worked on the first generation of wireless digital assistants, known as PDA. In December 1999 he launched Danger, creator of the Hiptop, a proto-smartphone, which was later bought by Microsoft. Rubin cofounded Android in 2003 and sold it to Google in 2005, moving to the firm. In December 2013, Rubin started management of the robotics division of Google, before leaving on 30 October 2014 to start an incubator for hardware startups. Rubin and his wife, Rie, also own and operate Voyageur du Temps, a bakery in Los Altos, CA.

The idea would be to rely on voice commands and AI to autonomously complete tasks for its users instead of always trying to capture and hold their attention.

'You can be off enjoying your life, having that dinner, without touching your phone, and you can trust your phone to do things on your behalf,' Rubin said in 2018.

The few photos and brief video of 'Project Gem' released so far focus on the unusual form factor more than the interface.

The images show a slick, metallic case made from colorshift material, which dramatically alters the hue of the phone depending on the angle you're viewing it on.

The screen can accommodate up to four apps as small stackable blocks, which appear to be operable both as small widgets and as expanded fullscreen interfaces.

The images show, Uber, a Calendar app, a Weather feed, and a Maps app, a music player, and a watch face, which can be combined in combinations of four.

Essential's 'Project Gem' phone is made with colorshift material that alters the hue of the case depending on what angle it's seen from.

Essential's first product, the Essential Phone, was released in 2017 for $699, and which featured a powerful camera.

The Essential Phone received generally positive reviews but was discontinued at the end of last year.

The company claimed it had sold out of its initial stock and rather than manufacture more it wanted to focus on future products.

The company is also working on a voice-controlled home assistant, called Essential Home.

Rubin was a controversial figure before he left Google, where it was reported he had a string of mistresses kept in what was described as 'an ownership relationship' and allegedly paid for by funds diverted from Google.
description: Android creator Andy Rubin is trying to change the landscape of the smartphone industry yet again with 'Project Gem,' an elongated new device meant to be usable at a glance.
